docs.lead_paragraph: The drug company GlaxoSmithKline hopes that making its research available to scientists will lead to safer, more effective drugs.

headline.seo: Glaxo Opens Door to Data on Its Research
headline.main: Glaxo Opens Door to Data on Research
headline.print_headline: Glaxo Opens Door to Data On Research

docs.abstract: GlaxoSmithKline plans to open up much of its drug research to scientists, hoping it will lead to safer, more effective drugs; move, first for a major drug firm, is apparent effort to deflect criticism that important clinical trial information often is not disclosed.
docs.snippet: The drug company GlaxoSmithKline hopes that making its research available to scientists will lead to safer, more effective drugs.

docs.abstract: Door-to-door sales and franchising are being used by a group called Living Goods to get needed health products to people in Africa.
docs.snippet: Door-to-door sales and franchising are being used by a group called Living Goods to get needed health products to people in Africa.

docs.lead_paragraph: The demise of St. Vincent’s Hospital in Greenwich Village two years ago has led to a struggle for health care supremacy, offering a glimpse at what might be the future of urban medicine.

headline.seo: After Losing St. Vincent’s Hospital, Manhattan Sees Rise in Clinic Care
headline.main: New Style of Health Care Emerges to Fill Hospital’s Void
headline.print_headline: Walk-In Clinics Filling Hospital Void Downtown

docs.abstract: Demise of St Vincent’s Hospital in Greenwich Village in 2010 has led to a struggle for health care supremacy in Lower Manhattan, offering a glimpse at what might be the future of urban medicine; walk-in clinics are filling hospital's void, hoping to show they are more efficient and consumer-friendly than a hospital-based system; some are already forming relationships with hospitals.
docs.snippet: The demise of St. Vincent’s Hospital in Greenwich Village two years ago has led to a struggle for health care supremacy, offering a glimpse at what might be the future of urban medicine.

keywords.value: New York University Langone Medical Center
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: More hospitals and medical practices are adopting videoconferencing to treat patients, as Nantucket’s hospital has, finding that in many cases tele-treating can stand in for an office visit.

headline.seo: Nantucket Hospital Uses Telemedicine as Bridge - The Digital Doctor
headline.main: With Telemedicine as Bridge, No Hospital Is an Island
headline.print_headline: With Telemedicine as Bridge, No Hospital Is an Island

docs.abstract: Some hospitals and medical practices are adopting videoconferencing technology as an affordable and effective way for doctors to examine patients without seeing them in person; method is especially useful in remote locations or in medical specialties that face a shortage of physicians.
docs.snippet: More hospitals and medical practices are adopting videoconferencing to treat patients, as Nantucket’s hospital has, finding that in many cases tele-treating can stand in for an office visit.

docs.lead_paragraph: Medical care has improved greatly in the last century, but even with technological advances it remains far from perfect.

headline.seo: A Century of Progress Comes With Complications - The Digital Doctor
headline.main: Strides in Medicine, and Their Price
headline.print_headline: Strides in Medicine, and Their Price

docs.abstract: Dr Lawrence K Altman essay notes that technological advances have allowed medicine to progress more in the last century than in all of previous history; warns that over-reliance on technology, especially on testing and imaging, can lead to abuse by doctors who do not sufficiently rely on their own observational powers.
docs.snippet: Medical care has improved greatly in the last century, but even with technological advances it remains far from perfect.

docs.lead_paragraph: Shinya Yamanaka and John B. Gurdon, the two scientists who were awarded the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine on Monday, helped lay the foundation for regenerative medicine.

headline.seo: Gurdon and Yamanaka Win Nobel Prize for Stem Cell Research
headline.main: Cloning and Stem Cell Work Earns Nobel
headline.print_headline: Cloning and Stem Cell Work Earns Nobel

docs.abstract: John B Gurdon and Shinya Yamanaka are awarded Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for their foundational work in regenerative medicine; their discoveries, which occurred fifty years apart, concern manipulation of living cells and lie at the heart of techniques for cloning animals and generating stem cells.
docs.snippet: Shinya Yamanaka and John B. Gurdon, the two scientists who were awarded the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine on Monday, helped lay the foundation for regenerative medicine.

headline.print_headline: Technology That Involves Teenagers in Their Health

docs.abstract: Some pediatricians have found a way to reach adolescents where they feel at home: via texting, blogs and social networks like Facebook and Twitter.
docs.snippet: Some pediatricians have found a way to reach adolescents where they feel at home: via texting, blogs and social networks like Facebook and Twitter.
